item.title: RBNZ Policymaker’s Closed-Door Talk Raises Transparency Concerns
item.description: An external member of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand’s Monetary Policy Committee will give a rare presentation today, but it will be behind closed doors.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) headquarters, left, stands in Wellington, New Zealand, on Thursday, Aug. 9, 2018. New Zealand's central bank said it expects to keep interest rates at a record low for another two years as the outlook for economic growth weakens.

item.title: US Tariff Revenue Hits Fresh Record, Helping Shrink May Deficit
item.description: US customs duties climbed to a record in May, helping shrink the budget deficit for the month, while doubts remain about the persistence of the inflows as the Trump administration negotiates with trading partners and faces a judicial challenge over its levies.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

President Donald Trump blasted China for retaliating against his sweeping tariff plan and vowed his economic policies will never change, as the prospect of a trade war wreaked more havoc on the global economy.

item.title: Bessent Says $2 Trillion Reasonable for Dollar Stablecoin Market
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that dollar-linked stablecoins could hit $2 trillion or even more as he reiterated the potential for these digital assets to strengthen the greenback’s position in the global financial system.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Senate Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Bessent credited President Donald Trump's policies for a slowdown in US inflation, and said he had challenged a "decades-old status quo" on trade.

item.title: Why China Can Afford to Wait for a Deal, and the US Can’t
item.description: On this episode of Trumponomics, we discuss the status of Washington’s trade war negotiations with Beijing, and why Xi Jinping still has the upper hand.

media:content.media:description: He Lifeng, China's vice premier, departs following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. The US and China resumed talks into a second day, with financial markets on edge as the world's largest economies try to agree to allow exports of key tech and industrial goods and avoid escalating their trade war.
